rounds.response:
Let me evaluate Player 0's offer: they want 1 Ore from me in exchange for 2 Wheat + 1 Wood.

Value of what I’d receive:  
2 Wheat × 5 = 10  
1 Wood × 8 = 8  
Total incoming = 18

Value of what I’d give away:  
1 Ore × 40 = 40

Net value change = 18 – 40 = –22. The trade would cost me 22 points. 

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me first reason about whether Player 0’s latest offer is advantageous or not.

Current values:
- 2 Wood = 2 × 8 = 16  
- 1 Wheat = 1 × 5 = 5  
Total offered value = 21  

- 1 Ore = 40  
- 2 Brick = 2 × 26 = 52  
Total requested value = 92  

So Player 0 is effectively asking for 92 value while giving me only 21.  
Net change to my bundle = +21 – 92 = –71 value—an obvious loss.  
Therefore I must deny this offer.

I also want to look for a win-win trade window.  
To raise my bundle value I should sell Sheep (value 14 yet I have 21 of them) for items that are worth more per unit—Ore (40) or Brick (26)—while giving up as few high-value cards as possible.  
A 2:1 Sheep-for-Ore (essentially) feels fair on my end (2 Sheep = 28 value, 1 Ore = 40) and still gives my opponent a surplus of +12 if they value Sheep highly. I’ll be conservative and only offer two Sheep plus a token Wheat for one Ore.

[Deny]  
[Offer: 2 Sheep, 1 Wheat -> 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
Let me analyze the current situation:

Current values:
- Wheat: 5 (I have 9)
- Wood: 8 (I have 22)
- Sheep: 14 (I have 21)
- Brick: 26 (I have 23)
- Ore: 40 (I have 11)

The latest offer from Player 0: 2 Sheep (28 value), 1 Ore (40 value) → 1 Wood (8 value), 2 Brick (52 value)

This is a terrible offer for me - I'm giving up 68 value for only 60 value, a net loss of 8. I should reject this.

Looking at my resources, I have a lot of Wood (22) and Sheep (21), but I'm relatively low on Ore (11) which has the highest value. I should try to acquire more Ore while giving up some of my excess resources.

[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Wood -> 1 Ore, 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
Turn 6 – Player 1 reflects:

Current valuation of my bundle:
• Wheat  9 × 5  = 45
• Wood  22 × 8   = 176
• Sheep 21 × 14 = 294
• Brick 23 × 26 = 598
• Ore  11 × 40 = 440
Total value = 1 553

Their last offer asks me to give up **3 Ore (120)** for **2 Wood (16) + 1 Wheat (5) = 21**, a net value drop of 99. I want to retain / grow my bundle value, not shrink it, so that previous proposal is obviously unacceptable.

However, Player 0’s repeated counters show they are desperate for Brick (they’ve asked for 1–2 Brick in every offer after turn 2). I have the most copies of Brick (23) and can spare some without hurting future opportunities.

Proposal: I’ll target more Ore (highest marginal value) while offering something Player 0 clearly wants—Brick. A fair exchange respecting ratio of valuations (Brick ≈ 26 : Ore ≈ 40) is 2 Brick for 1 Ore. To make the deal sweeter and guarantee acceptance, I’ll throw in a low-value Wheat.

[Offer: 2 Brick, 1 Wheat -> 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
After re-calculating the net-value for the latest incoming offer:

Incoming offer: [Offer: 2 Brick (52), 1 Wheat (5) → 1 Ore (40)]

- What I would give up: 2 Brick (52) + 1 Wheat (5) = 57 value  
- What I would receive: 1 Ore (40)  

Net loss = 57 – 40 = 17.  

Therefore the trade hurts my total value.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Believe Player 0 will only give up Ore if he receives close to full value.  
Quick value check of the last 4 offers I sent:

(–2 Sheep –1 Wheat → +1 Ore) –38 → +40 net +2  
(–3 Sheep –2 Wood → +1 Ore +1 Brick) –78 → +66 net –12  
(–2 Brick –1 Wheat → +1 Ore) –57 → +40 net –17  

None of these were even slightly attractive for him.

—————————————  What Player 0 seems to value  —————————————  
Towards winning he probably needs a late-game card that costs 2 Brick, 1 Wheat, 1 Ore (worth 101 to him) and he is still short of Ore.  He valued 1 Ore at at least 3 of any other resource.

————————————————  New tactic  ————————————————  
1. Sweeten my own offers by giving full (or more-than-full) value to his Ore.  
2. Exploit my glut of Sheep & Wood that are, to me, worth little compared with Brick/Ore.

Best one-shooter:

 - I give away 5 Sheep + 2 Wood  →  98 value given  
 - I receive 1 Ore               →  40 value gained  
 To me: –34 net, which still moves the final total upward because it locks a scarce resource, and keeps him from building the expensive card.

[Offer: 5 Sheep, 2 Wood -> 1 Ore]
